Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 39, Twenty-fifth of the YÄma Heaven

Furthermore, the YÄma Heaven King, the good time goose king, and the birds who expound the Dharma, in order to subdue the careless ones among the great ministers of the demon king, expounded the sÅ«tra of KÄÅ›yapa TathÄgata, which was transmitted and heard from the former celestial beings.
It has been said that the six kinds of pure dharmas eliminate dust and defilements. I will now explain the seventh defiled dharma, which the pure dharma can eliminate.
What is the defiled dharma?
Namely, seeing one's birthplace and giving rise to a joyful mind.
Joyfully seeing relatives, far away from eliminating it.

Knowledge and relatives, the mind always joyfully sees, always thinks of intimacy, day and night inseparable, not enjoying cultivating meditation and practicing, not approaching good teachers, making offerings to the Three Jewels, not thinking of future karma.
Among the three karmas, he does not speak for others, nor does he do it himself, but only thinks of relatives, wanting to see relatives, acquaintances, and old friends.
How does one manage one's livelihood?
How does one sustain oneself?
Having had this thought, he is covered by sorrow. Although he seeks liberation and dwells in the forest, he does not practice accordingly. This is ignorance, and the mind enters the sea of sorrow.

Having entered the sea of sorrow, he further enters the great sea of sorrow of birth, old age, sickness, and death, wanting to see relatives, acquaintances, and old friends, and enters the net of MÄra.
Because of seeing relatives, the mind of love grows. Invited to eat from house to house, he gives rise to a greedy mind and acts according to worldly customs.
Hearing the words of laypeople, the mind then delights in them.

Because of their attachment to pleasure, they lose their own benefit. Due to their foolishness, they do not fear the suffering of the evil destinies in the future. They do not contemplate the hells, hungry ghosts, animals, and other places of rebirth. They do not contemplate the present fears of old age, sickness, death, the suffering of separation from what is loved, and the suffering of encountering what is hated. They do not contemplate that all that is loved will eventually be separated from.

Fearing their relatives, acquaintances, and kinsmen, they go forth, but then return to being close to them. They enjoy their relatives, acquaintances, and old friends, and love others' food and drink. They frequently visit others' homes. When their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil destinies, either into the hells, or as hungry ghosts, or as animals. What they did in going forth, they all lose.
Having fallen into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals, they experience great suffering. Their relatives and acquaintances are unable to save them.
Therefore, all bhiká¹£us who fear hell, hungry ghosts, and animals should not enjoy seeing their relatives and acquaintances.
Because of being close to them, they will not gain any benefit.
They left the household life with the intention of ending craving, to cut off the net of craving;
Yet out of foolishness, they become attached to the net of craving, like a person who fears fire and flees from it, only to enter a great fire again.
In the same way, fearing the household life, they leave the household life to become renunciants, only to return to a fearful place. It is the same.
Abandoning relatives, they enter the forest, only to become attached again. This is being blind and ignorant, with uncontrolled faculties. This is called defiled Dharma.
What is the way to cut it off?
If one cannot cut it off with wisdom, or cannot restrain it or uphold it, one should avoid it for a long time.
If a foolish person cannot cut off craving with other skillful means, they should avoid it.
Because of not seeing, all loves are cut off.
All loved things will all be separated.

When one reaches the time of death, no one can save, except for the immeasurable hundreds of thousands of wholesome dharmas. The dharmas of goodness are the best saviors, not relatives can save a person, nor brothers.
Thus, a bhiká¹£u abandons relatives, dwells alone in a quiet place, and can cut off defiled dharmas.
When old, sick, and dying, relatives cannot protect and save.
The bhiká¹£u thus contemplates, cuts off all loves, and either attains slight thinness. This is called the bhiká¹£u cutting off the love of relatives.
Next, the renunciant cuts off the eighth defiled dharma.
What is the defiled dharma?
Namely, meaningless speech, which is cut off by right speech.
If a layperson speaks meaningless words, he is despised by the crowd like a weed.
Meaningful speech is the foremost wealth, which cannot be compared to other kinds of wealth;
Meaningless speech, even if one is wealthy and happy, is still considered poor.
Empty and meaningless speech is empty and unreal, and one is despised by others, just like a sheep. Without the wealth of speech, the wise regard one as an animal, the foremost in contempt.
How does one cut off empty and meaningless speech?
It is called right speech.
Right speech has two aspects. What are the two?
First, silence;
Second, the four kinds of right speech.
What are the four?
First, not speaking falsely;ğŸ”½Second, not speaking harshly;
Third, not speaking divisively;
Fourth, not speaking destructively.
This is called right speech.
Whether lay or ordained, if one can do this, one will not be despised.
Lay and ordained people are quickly despised by others for six reasons.
What are the six?
They are meaningless speech, barging into people's homes, greedily desiring others' food, sitting in a superior position, and speaking falsely without substance.
These six things are despised by people. Whether at home or as a renunciant, one should avoid these things.
Furthermore, the ninth defiled stain can be eliminated by pure dharmas.
How do pure dharmas eliminate defiled dharmas?
It is said that the dharma of lightness and agitation can be eliminated by right abiding.
The dharma of lightness and agitation obstructs all dharmas.

Because the nature of the mind is light and agitated, one lacks faith and awareness, does not know what to do in the world, does not know language, does not know the proper time, and does not associate with good friends.
Because of the negligence of lightness and agitation, one cannot understand worldly dharmas.
In this way, the evil stain of lightness and agitation can ruin the present and future, and one will not attain benefits.
Whether at home or as a renunciant, one should eliminate lightness and agitation with the pure dharma of right abiding.

Whether at home or ordained, if one's body, speech, and mind are free from agitation and properly abiding, one will be honored by the assembly, with right precepts, right wisdom, and right intention free from the realm of Mara, and will be replete with wholesome qualities, ultimately attaining nirvana.
In worldly matters, the wise praise this.
One will be able to accomplish all worldly tasks and be honored by the assembly.
Wherever one goes, one will always attain peace and happiness, and one's undertakings will be successful.
Thus, whether at home or ordained, if one is free from frivolous agitation, one will be praised by all people.'

Furthermore, the YÄma Heaven King MaudgalyÄyana spoke to the assembly of birds that expound the Dharma, the king of good timing geese, and the negligent ministers of the demon king, using a sÅ«tra of KÄÅ›yapa Buddha that he had heard in sequence from the former celestial sons, to expound to the celestial assembly.
Next, the tenth defiled dharma can be despised and reviled, and is abandoned by the wise.
What is the defiled dharma?
It is called poverty.
There are two kinds of poverty:
First, poverty in precepts;
second, poverty in wisdom.
There are two more kinds:
First, poverty in giving;
second, poverty in wisdom.
There are two more kinds:
First, poverty in family lineage;
second, poverty in views.
There are two more kinds:
First, poverty in precious things;
second, poverty in teachers and elders.
There are two more kinds:
First, poverty in relatives;
second, poverty in friends and acquaintances.
All kinds of poverty can be despised, whether it is a man or a woman.
How can it be eliminated?
It is called giving.
All kinds of poverty can be eliminated by giving, just as the light of a lamp can dispel darkness.
All kinds of ignorance can be eliminated by wisdom.
All kinds of wrong views can be eliminated by right views.
In this way, non-dharma can be eliminated by dharma.
The most supreme, loved and embraced by all the wise, cutting off the multitude of evil paths, peaceful and secure in both the present and future lives.
What is giving?

There are many kinds of giving, namely, the giving of wisdom, the giving of precepts, the giving of Dharma, the giving of comfort, the giving of showing the right path, the giving of showing the way for those who have lost their way, the giving of showing water for those who are traveling, the giving of life, the giving of necessities, the giving of fearlessness, the giving of true words, the giving of cutting off doubts, the giving of the five precepts, the giving of the precepts of leaving the household life, the giving of the precepts in their entirety, the giving of medicine for the sick, the giving of eyes, and so forth.

Such various kinds of giving can benefit both the present and future lives, just like parents, always thinking of and cultivating oneself, cutting off all poverty, cutting off evil paths, and receiving peace and happiness among gods and humans.
Having received happiness, one will ultimately attain nirvana.
Such giving can cut off poverty. Therefore, the wise should practice giving.
Furthermore, the eleventh dark dharma can bind one to birth and death, and obscure all dharmas.
What is the dark dharma?
It is called ignorance.
Immeasurable ignorance, up to the darkness of ignorance, binds all births.
The mass of all darkness binds one's neck. Ignorance is like a knife, like fire, like poison.

Ignorance is also like all ignorance. The causes and conditions of all ignorance can cause one to transmigrate through all hells, hungry ghosts, and animals. It can bind sentient beings, causing them to transmigrate.
How can such an enemy and defilement be eliminated?
It is called the wisdom without outflows.
It is like a bright lamp, a savior, a refuge, for all sentient beings, like a father, like a mother.
It is like a doctor and also like good medicine. It cuts off the bonds of ignorance and does not arise again, like cutting off the roots of a tree, the tree does not grow.
Just as fire burns firewood and does not grow again, and just as flowing water does not flow back, so it is with the burning of ignorance by the wisdom of no outflows, which does not grow again.
Therefore, one should diligently cultivate and practice at all times, using the wisdom of no outflows to eliminate ignorance.
These eleven kinds of dharmas that have been explained are the roots of negligence.
Following negligence, born from negligence, therefore one should eliminate all negligence.
The roots of all negligence are all without benefit, able to accomplish negligence.
Just as all medicinal herbs, trees, forests, flowing streams, rivers, ponds, embankments, cities, villages, gardens, forests, and the king of Mount Sumeru all depend on the great earth,
so it is with all hells, hungry ghosts, and animals, which also depend on negligence.
Therefore, the wise should abandon it.
At that time, the king of the YÄma Heaven spoke in verse, saying:
An old man's skin is wrinkled, and he walks with a cane,
Old and yet not knowing the Dharma, all due to indulgence.
Sickness destroys the body, and one lies down on a bed,
And yet one does not give rise to disgust, all due to foolishness.
If one encounters hunger and thirst, or enters a dangerous path,
And yet does not give rise to disgust, all due to indulgence.
If one experiences the separation of loved ones, and gives rise to suffering and distress,
All due to indulgence, the TathÄgata speaks thus.
If in the five destinies one fully experiences various sufferings,
Beings are always in distress, due to their foolishness.
Alas, not giving rise to disgust, in the cycle of birth and death,
The great wheel of karma turns, revolving without pause.
The three realms are all without joy, and there is not even a little permanence,
Thus, these foolish people do not know to give rise to disgust and detachment.
The sense objects are all empty, the three realms are like a dream,
All are suffering, those without eyes do not see or know.
Thus, these foolish people are harmed by negligence,
When the fear of death is about to arrive, there is no one who can block or rescue them.
For the sake of improper views, they disturb their minds and thoughts,
When the king of death is about to lead them away, people do not realize it.
When the king of death is about to arrive, he seizes people's minds of cherishing life,
The three kinds of harm bring no benefit and afflict all sentient beings.
The sufferings of old age, sickness, and death arise due to negligence,
In the pursuit that afflicts humans, negligence harms the gods;
Hunger and thirst afflict hungry ghosts, the suffering of hell afflicts them,
Animals are mostly foolish, and they harm each other;
Such various sufferings and afflictions torment all beings,
Because they follow unrighteous conduct and are negligent and foolish.
Just as various medicinal herbs grow on the great earth,
Negligence is also like this, increasing all afflictions.
As for the army of the demon king, the foremost ministers and others,
Destroy them with the vajra of wisdom, like sunlight dispelling darkness.
Among what is said here, know the merits and faults,
The fruits of negligence are suffering, the fruits of non-negligence are happiness.
Thus the king of the Heaven of YÄma spoke immeasurably,
The faults of negligence and the merits of non-negligence.
Old age, sickness, death, and various sufferings, separation from what is loved, being with what is hated,
Immeasurable calamities and afflictions fill the realm of birth and death.
If one knows the skillful means to prevent future suffering,
Evil karma is the cause of suffering, not creating evil karma is happiness.
Extinguishing afflictions is the greatest happiness, the wise say it is so,
This is the path to nirvana, truly expounded by the wise.
Subduing oneself, not being negligent, dwelling in a quiet place,
Being courageous, free from greedy thoughts, is not far from nirvana.
Free from enemies and friends, extinguishing desires for existence,
Not being negligent regarding objects, is not far from nirvana.
If one abandons evil and cultivates a compassionate mind,
One who fears birth and death is not far from nirvana.
Using wisdom to extinguish afflictions, the mind of wisdom is cool and refreshing,
Crossing over the defilements of laziness, is not far from nirvana.
Being in accord with the four truths, cutting off the three kinds of faults,
They are in control of their faculties, and are not far from nirvana.
Knowing the in-and-out breath, cultivating the two kinds of characteristics,
Understanding what is to be known with wisdom, they are not far from nirvana.
If one is free from the fear of wrongdoing, if one's mind delights in non-attachment,
Because one is able to reach the other shore, one is therefore called a sage.'
In this way, the king of the Heaven of YÄma spoke the sÅ«tra of the true Dharma of KÄÅ›yapa TathÄgata for the assembly of birds that expound the Dharma and the king of good time geese.
Because of being free from negligence, in this way the wonderful sounds of the true Dharma and discipline were courageously expounded.
At that time, the army of the demon king and the negligent ministers, having heard the true Dharma, thought like this:
'We are now unable to turn the king of the Heaven of YÄma away from this Dharma.
The profound Dharma that is difficult to understand cannot be turned back.'
Having had this thought, they fully informed their companions:
'Now, this SuyÄma is unmoved by this Dharma path, not even a single word.'

Having thought this together, the demon ministers, weak in power, their original intention to destroy defeated, their great authority lost, flew up into the sky and in an instant returned to the palace of MÄra PÄpÄ«yÄn in the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin Heaven.
Having arrived, all the demons asked the messenger, saying:
'Did you accomplish what you set out to do?
Is the matter concluded?'
When the three great ministers heard these words, they said to the demon king:
'Your Majesty!
We have lost our power. The king of the YÄma Heaven, SuyÄma, has great wisdom. In the true Dharma, not even a single word can be moved.
And his heavenly beings are also like this. We cannot disturb them.'
Then, when MÄra PÄpÄ«yÄn heard these words, he thought like this:
'I can cause the gods who indulge in carelessness to abide in desire.
Although they have great power, because of their carelessness, they abide within my realm.'
Having thought this, he said to the demon horde:
'Later I will be able to destroy the Heaven of the Thirty-three. You need not be in a hurry.
I have great power and can completely destroy and disturb all the heavenly multitudes. Later I will destroy them.'

When Mara PÄpÄ«yÄn had said this, he again enjoyed the unequalled six desires and increased his carelessness to immeasurable levels, achieving great bliss.ğŸ”½The king of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, together with the king of good timing geese and the assembly of birds who expound the Dharma, spoke immeasurable kinds of Dharma. The careless army of demons having already retreated, the heavenly multitudes had accomplished what needed to be done.

At that time, the newly born assembly of gods, playing and enjoying themselves, came to the place where the king of the Heaven of the Thirty-three expounded the Dharma, as well as to the place of the king of good timing geese and the assembly of birds who expound the Dharma.
At that time, the king of the YÄma Heaven saw these gods and said to Good Time:
'You see these gods who are indulging in pleasures coming here.
I will now go to the tranquil garden and forest.'
Having said this, he flew up into the sky and entered the tranquil forest.

These gods roamed about carelessly, fully endowed with the five desires, enjoying themselves in the gardens, forests, and ponds, until the karma they had accumulated through craving was exhausted, and they transmigrated according to their karma, falling into the hells, the realm of hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.

If they had any remaining karma and were reborn among humans, they would be wealthy and prosperous, be great people in the world, either a great king or a great minister, in a place of great joy, loved by the people.
This is due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma. With their wisdom of hearing, they see:
The place where the YÄma gods reside is called One-sided Happiness.
What karma do sentient beings have that causes them to be born in that place?
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
There are good people who uphold the precepts, do not kill or steal, as explained above, and also abandon sexual misconduct.
They do not engage in sexual misconduct, which is the most difficult to uphold, and are able to abandon and not commit it.
If they see male and female animals copulating, they do not give rise to thoughts, abandon and do not wish to see, and also do not think about it.

They give rise to a fearful mind regarding the retribution for sexual misconduct, and therefore abandon it. When they see those engaging in sexual misconduct, they encourage them to refrain from it, explain the retribution for sexual misconduct, and cause them to abide in the good path.
For this reason, they speak such Dharma words:
'This sexual misconduct will result in an unloved retribution, and one will definitely fall into the hells.'
Having themselves not committed it, they also teach others not to commit it.
Such people benefit themselves and others. When their body perishes and their life ends, they are born in the good destinies, in the Heaven of YÄma, in the realm of one-sided pleasure.
Due to their good karma, their happiness is always uninterrupted, and immeasurable pleasures all increase.
In this realm there are various gardens and forests that are delightful to behold.
In the forest of wishes, all sensual pleasures are obtained as one thinks of them, and one enjoys pleasures there in the gardens and forests.
There are various gardens and forests for the newly born gods:
One is called the forest of blissful light;
The second is called the forest of blissful flowing waters;
The third is called the forest of blissful mountain clusters.

There are lotus ponds called the mixed pond and the fragrant flowing pond, and there are also gardens, forests, and mountains. The gods' merits are complete in countless ways, and the forests and ponds are delightful.

translated: The newly born celestial beings play and enjoy themselves, a thousand times more meritorious than before. The ponds are called Jewel Railing Pond, Various Birds' Music Pond, Celestial Joy Pond, Constant Play Pond, Pleasure Pond, Undisturbed Pond, Real Existence Pond, and Seeing Future Existence Pond. The ponds are surrounded by celestial birds with beautiful voices, perfect colors and forms filling the ponds. Wish-fulfilling trees line the ponds, with immeasurable merits all complete.
Due to good karma, they enjoy the five desires with innumerable celestial maidens.
The celestial beings' forms follow their thoughts and act accordingly. They enjoy watching and never leave. They observe in sequence and enjoy the five desires.
Because of upholding precepts and accumulating good karma, they attain such rewards.
They play, sing, and dance in the flower ponds, enjoying the five desires.
In this way, the five desires are like a forest of thirst and love, and he is surrounded by celestial maidens in the jeweled and adorned pond.
Again, he goes to other lotus ponds and adorned mountains to play and enjoy himself. With celestial garlands and celestial garments, the pleasures of the five senses are delightful to the eyes.
Ascending this mountain, he wishes to experience happiness. The mountain peak he ascends is called Mountain Valley, which is very delightful.

On that mountain, there are other gods who adorn themselves with celestial garlands and celestial garments. They come down from Mount Gold, surrounded by celestial multitudes, playing and descending in hundreds of thousands.
The newly born celestial son sees the celestial multitudes and asks the celestial maidens:
Just as those celestial multitudes enjoy themselves with the celestial maidens, will I also enjoy myself in the same way?
The celestial maidens say:
May it be as you wish.

At that time, the newly born celestial son, knowing the celestial maiden's thoughts, surrounded by the celestial maidens, played and amused himself, supremely joyful, with the sounds of the five musical instruments as his songs.
The two groups gathered together, playing and enjoying themselves without knowing enough.
On the mountain, there was a bird called the Mountain Crown Peacock King, who spoke in verse to the celestial multitudes, saying:
The world is adorned by karma, and the heavens are also adorned by karma.
Because the heavenly realms are impermanent, when karma is exhausted, they are destroyed.
In the world, one loves union but not separation.
Where there is union, there must be separation. This is the way of the world.
The mind loves and delights in pleasures, deceived by sense objects.
The lives of the celestial beings quickly come to an end, like the arising and ceasing of the mind.
Old age, sickness, and death destroy and separate all people.
This law of death is always present, but the foolish do not realize it.
Old age and death come in succession, and the time of death is about to arrive.
The army of illness can destroy, but the foolish are unaware.
The six kinds of loss of the human body, the five faculties can destroy,
Like a person who loses the right path, everywhere is obstructed.
If a person contemplates cause and effect, always contemplating without losing,
This person sees the true fruit, and later does not give rise to regret.
If a person truly sees the objects of the senses and is not attached,
This person will be able to quickly escape from the objects of desire.
If one escapes from the net of desire, one will cross the evil wilderness,
And be able to stay far away from the fire of heedlessness, this person has great wisdom.
The five kinds of great fears destroy the entire world,
Because of one's own karma, old age, illness, death, and separation.

Thus, the peacock king Bodhisattva, adorned with various ornaments, by the power of his vow, takes on the body of a peacock, benefiting others and benefiting the peacocks, teaching the Dharma to the gods and eliminating their carelessness.

At that time, the assembly of gods sees the newly born god, their minds filled with joy. Due to carelessness, they do not believe or accept the words of good Dharma, but sing, dance, play, and enjoy themselves with the sounds of the five musical instruments.

In the mountain peaks and gardens, there are countless indescribable golden light caves and wish-fulfilling forests adorning the mountain, with countless birds, hundreds of thousands of rivers, and flower forests.
Together with the celestial maidens, endowed with all desires, heavenly pleasures complete, and countless amusements.
In this way, the assembly of gods plays and gradually ascends Mount Mixed Jewels.
On this mountain there are seven-jeweled trees and a forest of wish-fulfilling trees adorning the mountain, five yojanas long and wide.
In this forest there is a peacock king named Various Adornments, who resides in this forest to expound the Dharma for the devas.

In order to cause the sons of the devas and the celestial maidens to abandon heedlessness, and because he loves to expound the Dharma, he roams in the gardens and forests, in the lotus forests, in the various mixed forests, in the rivers, springs, flowing waters, and mountain peaks, in the places adorned with jewels, in the places with the wonderful sounds of hundreds of thousands of birds, in the places adorned by all the celestial hosts, and in the places adorned by the celestial maidens. There are many sons of the devas and celestial maidens who unite to experience pleasure, and the peacock king then goes to them.
Due to good karma, they experience various pleasures and all kinds of amusements. Such amusements are immeasurable and indescribable, and everything is obtained as one wishes.

At that time, the peacock king, in the jeweled peaks of the maá¹‡i-studded mountain, saw the heavenly multitudes enjoying the pleasures of indulgence. In order to cause the heavenly multitudes to be free from indulgence, he spoke a verse, saying:
Whether in the present or future, forms and objects are never satisfying.
Recollecting, one is burned by the fire, and repeatedly seeks out objects.
Although one may attain rebirth in the heavens, having been born, one returns to extinction.
Bound by the net of karma, one falls again into the hells,
Emerging to receive the births of ghosts and animals, experiencing immeasurable suffering and distress.
Sentient beings travel the five paths, due to the causes and conditions of karma.
Sentient beings have various karmas, extremely numerous and immeasurable,
Therefore they attain various fruits.
Because karma is exhausted, one falls back. Where there is birth, there is also cessation.
One who sees the true reality is able to see the heavenly retributions.
When this death is about to arrive, one's life is then destroyed,
All that can disturb and afflict, the foolish are unaware of.
Using various methods to subdue, speaking of various benefits,
The heavenly beings are deluded by pleasure, and do not give rise to disgust and detachment.
Good words that accord with the Dharma, in both worlds one attains peace and happiness,
The foolish do not accept them, later they will give rise to great regret.
Using many methods to subdue, true words and clear meaning,
But the heavens are attached to heedlessness, not knowing true benefits.
The enemy of death harms the heavenly life, with great power none can save,
With great power rushing quickly, when death arrives it is too late.
The heavens, dragons, yakshas, gandharvas, and pi shas,
All are unable to resist, therefore the power of death is great.
If one knows the power and no power, this person truly knows karma,
Not defiled by evil karma, not engaging in evil paths.
Always practicing all good, leaving behind the realm of evil,
Such a person who acts like this will have no suffering or distress.
Following the practice of the Dharma, increasing faith and diligence,
In accord with the power of samÄdhi, like a mother benefiting her child.
The good Dharma can save and protect all in the five destinies,
Neither father nor mother has the power to go there.
Faith and obedience to the true Dharma can save one from the suffering of the evil destinies,
Wherever one goes, faith always has great power.
Like a lamp that can dispel darkness, like a patient obtaining good medicine,
Like the blind obtaining eyes, like the poor obtaining wealth,
Like a person drowning in water, faith is a great ship and raft,
If a person engages in heedless conduct, faith can eliminate it.
At the time of death, because of faith, one can eliminate the ocean of birth and existence,
Then one attains the abode of tranquility, as spoken by the ancient sages.
Because of attaining the power of faith, it is called the practice of right wisdom.
Faith, non-negligence, diligence, contentment,
Gathering wisdom, and befriending the virtuous - these six are the causes of liberation.
